dialogues.speaker: NOW CAVE 2 DAY 20
dialogues.text: TWENTY MINUTES LATER: HAROLD & TAYLOR have tunnelled a nu yards into the mound of snow when they come to the first the BIG TENT. HAROLD clears away more snow with his hands uses his ice axe to rip a hole in the tent which, incredi retained some of its structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE THE TENT: we see a jumble of BODIES. HAROLD grabs nearest head ~ TAKANE’S, whose eyes register shock ~ and

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Hey. Thanks. God --~- HAROLD shines a PENLIGHT into the pile of bodies ...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Everybody else okay? After weak ACKNOWLEDGMENTS, HAROLD & TAYLOR help all FOUR struggle out of the tent and down the tunnel towards the 21_:_ EXT + MOQSE’S TOOTH : DAY _ i221

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four rescued CLIMBERS stand beyond the avalanche site exercising life back into cramped limbs. CLAYBORN in his grasping a piece of his hi-tech EQUIPMENT as a kind of ta

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: How did you find us? TAYLOR picks up the ROPE, which leads from his and Harold into the snow cave,

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: ~ Your idea?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Harold’s,

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: What about the other tent? (TAYLOR SHAKES HIS HEAD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better start digging! Mark! Jack! Meanwhile HAROLD is standing on the edge of the precipice looking down the thousand foot drop to the glacier below.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hey! Look!  28 HAROLD'S POV: some of the avalanche has gone over the edg dashed itself to powder on the moraine at the foot of the wall, Just visible amidst the windblown debris is a flutt rag of the bright RED FABRIC that was the twins’ tent. HAROLD turns away from the edge, distraught, just as TAYL CLAYBORN rush up to look over for themselves. While CLAYB throws the useless piece of equipment over the edge ... TAYLOR goes to comfort HAROLD, who is close to tears. In the LOUNGE of the ALPINE CLUB, with its atmosphere of tradition of pioneering in this prime wilderness region o USA, PHOTOGRAPHS of intrepid climbers line the wood-panel walls. In the doorway, we see two grizzled summit VETERAN each other with some arcane, private~joke hand signal; th immediately fall to reminiscing about some high altitude Meanwhile TAYLOR sits with CLAYBORN over a drink. While t man looks very business-like in his rather severe suit, T dresses as usual more flamboyantly.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I guess it leaves kind of a hole in your team. CLAYBORN deflects this challenge with his best poker face

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Got anyone in mind to fill it?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: You’re volunteering, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Depends on where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Could be just about anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: “Waiting for permission" means the Himalayas.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. We might be going ski trekking in the Urals.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Oh come on Clayborn, it’s one of the big ones. You wouldn’t be in it otherwise.  CLAYBORN gazes 29g noncommittally out the window at one of his mirror-glass SCRAPERS that towers above them ...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: I never talk about a deal until it’s signed.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Is it Everest? (NO REACTION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Karakoram?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: (TAYLOR IS VERY WARM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What concern is it of yours?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’m the best climber I know who's never been over 8000m.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: So what’s stopping you?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: The big ones take time. I’ve never given myself that time, But I’m not getting any younger here, and this just seems right.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: You haven’t told me WHY I should take you and ~-- and your friend?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: His name’s Harold Jamison, and he saved your life goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: That’s not a reason to take him. Or you.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’ve climbed with Harold fifteen years. We're good together, and we’re hungry. You need two guys. Why NOT take us?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Maybe I just don’t like having my decisions made for me?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: When are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Three weeks.  30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: For as long as it takes,

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Maybe this decision is making itself? Who else is on the list?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s your problem with Dallas Woolf?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Ask him what’s his with me!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: I already did. I just don't need to be responsible for the first murder at 28,000 feet.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: It's K2, isn’t it?! Touche! CLAYBORN tries to brazen it out, but now TAYLOR k this is the destination.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Isn’t it?tt

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: I’1l put it to the other members of the team.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: It's your team, You can make the decision right here.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: (STANDING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only decision I’m prepared to make right here is "no", TAYLOR finally drops his case for an instant verdict, and

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I want to climb K2 more than anything in the world. It’s been my dream for ever. Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Mine too. Taylor. (SHAKING HANDS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I?ll cail you.  31

dialogues.speaker: RY
dialogues.text: While his young assistant WALKER shuffles papers, TAYLOR around the GLICKERS, SENIOR & JUNIOR, who sit at a cheap a small bare room with a glass door panel - through which COURT OFFICIALS, LAWYERS, WITNESSES ete bustling about OU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angry TAYLOR waves a piece of PAPER in the air as the frightened men shift awkwardly in their seats. These woul mafiosi have the air of over-ambitious losers who have be burned at both ends in some sordid underworld embroglio.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: How come this is the first I know about this? (SNR GLARES AT JNR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’d I say when you jerk-off snuff-junkies begged me to take the case? Huh? I said "you gotta tell me everything". Did I say that? Tell me I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: Just get us a deal, We'll plead to conspiracy if they drop the first degree.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: How dumb are you? This is proof you had the guy offed.

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER JNR
dialogues.text: That was just like -~ a joke!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You’re not wrong. Since when does taking out a contract on a guy mean writing it down and fucking signing it?

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER JINR
dialogues.text: The guy was gonna kill us for chrissakes!

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: Just tell us what we gotta do to get off the hook here.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Commit suicide.

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: I'm paying you some tough bread smartass. Now get us out of this!  32

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: How?!? You want me to bribe the judge, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: All right! How much would it cost? TAYLOR looks ‘at WALKER, smiles, shakes his head, and spi piece of paper onto the table in front of the sweating ho

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You’re going down Glicker.

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: What? !? Just now, a PORTABLE PHONE RINGS; WALKER answers it, then it to TAYLOR, who listens, his smile broadening ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: ~~-- Thanks Phillip. Thanks! TAYLOR excitedly hands the phone back to WALKER and gestu him that they’re out of there. WALKER shrugs and starts s papers back into a briefcase. .

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: Hey! I’m talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Not any more you're not,

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: What the hell’s the problem? I’1l pop for the judge - what-~ ever it takes, you know ~~--—

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Goodbye Glicker.

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: Where you goin’? Someone offering you more money, is that it? So tell me ~ how much you need? Ten? --- Twenty? TAYLOR & WALKER are half-way out the door now, the irate GLICKER following them into the CORRIDOR ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: The amount of money you'd need to keep me in this room, I haven’t heard about. OUT IN THE CORRIDOR now, watched by COURT VISITORS, the d GLICKER grabs TAYLOR by the throat.  33

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: You’re my attorney goddammit! You can’t dump me in it like this! You crazy? TAYLOR impassively looks down at GLICKER’S hands around h throat ~ then glances up at a concerned POLICE OFFICER co down the corridor towards him.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Okay Taylor?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Take this boy to Court Four will you Barney? Excitement seems to be getting to him. BARNEY grabs GLICKER SNR and starts to haul him off down corridor. GLICKER SCREAMS after the departing TAYLOR:

dialogues.speaker: GLICKER SNR
dialogues.text: I’1L find you, you fuck! I’11 find you and I’ll feed you to my fucking pit bulls! GLICKER is trying to pull away from BARNEY, who is now he TWO OTHER COPS in trying to subdue the crazed gangster -- TAYLOR makes his exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD is bent over his ELECTRON MICROSCOPE as TAYLOR bur the lab...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Shove that crap in the freezer H, We're on!

dialogues.speaker: -- HAROLD
dialogues.text: On for what?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Clayborn wants us on the bus —~= to K2!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: He just called. We’re leaving in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What do you mean "we"?  34 HAROLD is on his feet now, pacing TAYLOR around the room.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I mean we ~ you and I - are going to knock off the toughest fucking mountain in the world.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But -~- what did you tell him? Iocan’t leave in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You can do anything you want to do H.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: My grant review’s on the twenty- third. I’ve got to be here then.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Get it put forward,

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It doesn’t work like that.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Make it work like that.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I know that we've been talking about the big one for fifteen years. Here it is ~ on a plate.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You’1ll have to go without me.

dialogues.speaker: , TAYLOR
dialogues.text: He needs two guys to make up the team. I sold him on us ~ you and me ~ as a unit,

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You didn’t even ask me!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to talk about it until it was definite.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (BEAT) Find someone else.  35

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: No way. You don’t go, I don’t go. And that’s not happening.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You’re not listening to me Taylor. I can't go.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I been getting a lot of "can’t" from you recently. You’re letting the bullshit get on top of you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: My wife, and my kid, and my job are not bullshit - and I don’t intend to blow any of them.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (TURNING ON HIS HEEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let’s deal with the job first.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: To see what’s his name? Trenton.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Taylor!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I'll do a deal with you H. You got the grant, we'll forget the mountain. You don't get the grant, we'll forget the "can’t". Okay?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jesus! You're making it sound an like a party game. It's not —~ Just as the exasperated HAROLD is chasing TAYLOR out of t SHERMAN enters, looking for his colleague ...

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: Who’s this guy?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: My bete noir.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’m the best fucking friend you ever had, H, and one day I’m going to hear it from you.  36 252 INT : OUTSIDE TRENTON’S OFFICE : DAY 00000: 25 TAYLOR is about to barge straight through Trenton’s door also has a glass panel in it ~ when HAROLD grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Wait! Look! IN TRENTON'S OFFICE: TRENTON sits at his desk while our f femme fatale lays out a series of large format MAGNETIC R IMAGES - high-definition color x-rays - on a LIGHTBOX.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (WHISPERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that?!?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Miss Mammogram! I told you -=

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: She's looking for a grant? How much does she need? I'll give it to her.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Everybody wants to give it to her. Then, before HAROLD can restrain TAYLOR, he KNOCKS on Tre door, and enters the office, HAROLD following him in an a at damage limitation. TRENTON & the REDHEAD look up in su

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: Harold! What ~~? Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Taylor Tarantino. I’m Harold’s attorney.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: _ Taylor!

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Sorry to barge in Professor. My idea. We need an answer on Harold’s grant. TRENTON looks daggers at HAROLD, then:

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: Will you excuse us Ms Kurstow? This won't take a minute.  37 The REDHEAD smiles and leaves the room, TAYLOR'S eyes fol her. When she has gone:

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: Now what the hell is this all about?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I need Harold’s participation in something very important on the twenty-third. I figure you've already decided about his grant so --~ is he going to get it or not?

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: How did you get past my secretary?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Same way I get past all bullshit: I jump over it. Now come on - we’re talking about Harold's future here. What’s it going to be? TRENTON is standing now, He picks up a copy of HAROLD’S T CU: HAROLD’S NAME on the cover - flicks through it, and d wistfully back on the desk. Now TAYLOR picks it up and examines it ...

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: This is a good piece of work Harold. A very good piece of work. Better than the study that clinched my professorship I should say --- what we call “pure research" Mr Tarantino. TAYLOR looks at HAROLD significantly.

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: - But that was twenty years ago. When there was such a thing as a free lunch in these dumps. Now TRENTON is handling some of the Redhead's M.R. IMAGES

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: These Magnetic Resonance Images of Ms Kurstow’s are examples of applied research. The university is negotiating an R and D contract for this technology with --~ a large company, worth up to a hundred million dollars to us over the next ten years.  38

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: So the answer’s no.

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: Very reluctantly. I have no choice Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But without "pure" research, you've got nothing to apply.

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: This is a smal! faculty. We are not well endowed. We have to be realistic.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I call it short-sighted. You want me to do an appendix on future applications of my work?

dialogues.speaker: TRENTON
dialogues.text: You came in here demanding an immediate answer. You’ve got it. (INTO INTERCOM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms Kurstow may come back in now. (TO HAROLD: )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’re one of the best research scientists I know Harold. I’1l give you all the help I can to find another posting. I’m sorry. MS KURSTOW reenters the office. She smiles at HAROLD with serene inevitability ~ like a scientist looking at a beau but-doomed dinosaur. She offers hima “no hard feelings" h shake, but TAYLOR grabs HAROLD'S arm and pulls him to the

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Come on H ~ we're out of here. Thanks Trenton. 26_1_INT/EXT : SEATTLE STREETS : EVENING ot 26 THROUGH THE WINDSCREEN OF TAYLOR'S PORSCHE: we see TAYLOR HAROLD talking mute as they drive down quiet suburban str past MEN watering lawns after work, KIDS playing basketba against garage doors, WOMEN cooking dinner in brightly-li kitchens with the TV on for company. Then:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It’s a matter of perception.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: It’s a matter of evolution.  39 As they enter HAROLD'S STREET ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Look out here --~ you see people happy at home with their families --~ I see people who've given up fighting for existence. That's what I call living dangerously. 27:_INT/EXT: TAYLOR'S PORSCHE OUTSIDE HAROLD’S HOUSE: EVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As TAYLOR pulls up outside HAROLD’S HOUSE:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You want me to come in? HAROLD looks at the lighted windows of his home

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: One thing I’m still capable of is doing my own talking. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: So I can call Clayborn?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (BEAT) Yeah. Call him.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want me to wait? Til you’ve talked it over.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Get out of here. They do their blood brothers handshake, HAROLD gets out o car and treads heavily up the path to his front door ... 28 INT: HAROLD & CINDY’S LIVING ROOM : NIGHT 328

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD enters the living room, to see a delighted ERIC er quickly across the floor towards him, and CINDY, still in uniform, just beginning to prepare dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hi Eric. Hi Cind. He picks ERIC up, and then goes to kiss CINDY. She seems happy, and very pleased to see him.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Hello darling. Good day?  40

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Er -- fine. You started on something there? I thought we might go out for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Oh! Really? Sure - that’d be neat. I'11 go change.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Can I watch? CINDY winks at him and leads the way into their bedroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDY, wearing only bra and panties, stands making hersel the big mirror that faces the foot of their double bed, o she can see HAROLD playing rough and tumble with ERIC.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Where we gonna go?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Your choice.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: How about the Vietnamese? They're great with Eric.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Vietnamese. Fine. CINDY has just started applying her lipstick when she hap glance at her husband, and there is something about the w expression on his face as he plays with his son that stop mid~stroke.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: What is it H?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Something’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Nothing’s wrong. CINDY pauses another moment, before going back to her mak  41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUCH LATER THAT NIGHT: HAROLD & CINDY are lying naked und sheet in the dark when ERIC makes a small NOISE from his the adjoining room. CINDY is asleep, but HAROLD is wide a is about to get out of bed when ERIC quietens again. HAROLD lies on his back with his eyes open now, clearly t turns away from CINDY onto his side, and is about to slip bed when CINDY stirs ...

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: What is it H?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Can't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Dunno.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Yes you do.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I’m just going to get a drink of water.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (PULLING HIM BACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what’s the matter first. You’ve been weird all evening.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Look I just want to --—

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made you a promise Cind. (TWO BEATS) I want to break it.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Another mountain!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: But you said six months. You promised! You haven’t been home six days!  42

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Things’ve changed. Everything's different,

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Like what? Am I different?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You don’t love me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No ~~ yes! Of course I still love you.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You in love with somebody else?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Well what then?!?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We've been asked to go to K2.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It’s the chance of a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: The chance of a lifetime to get yourself killed! CINDY is out of bed now, raging naked around the room in -darkness. Beside the bed on Harold’s side is a BOOKSHELF which are a number of books, mostly about mountain climbi grabs several of them up, cracks them open, rips pages ou

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I've looked at these books H. “Savage Mountain" -- "Killer Mountain" -~ half the people who go to K2 don’t come back!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: K2’s not --- guys get killed on all kinds of mountains.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: But why do you want to die?  43

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don’t want to die.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Then why the hell do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I do it to feel alive!

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Thanks very much!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Cindy shut up and listen!

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You want to blow five years of work ~- your grant -- just so's the Italian Stallion can use you as his stooge again -~ The grain of truth in this stings HAROLD hard, and he ban raging woman against the wall, stunning her momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I’m NOT his stooge! I’m doing this mountain for ME!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Cindy I lost the fucking grant!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I lost my grant. It won’t be renewed. Finito. As of two ~ weeks time, I’m out of there.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Well thanks for telling me. She slaps him very hard across the face. Still feeling gu having pounded her, HAROLD wants the punishment.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Everything’s falling apart. And now this has come up --~

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (SLAPPING HIM AGAIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now THIS has come up! How inconvenient, huh?  44 Now it is HAROLD’s turn to lose all control and rage arou room, throwing and smashing things ...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You or the mountain, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Me or the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well I’m going to have both!

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: We won't be here when you get back! If you get back.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Then I’11 come and find you, wherever you are, and we'll start all over, and know how to do it right.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! Yes! Yes! Yes! CINDY is SCREAMING; HAROLD chases her round the room and her; she kicks and struggles; he forces her onto the bed; they fight, then they fuck. IN THE NEXT ROOM: ERIC listens to the new SOUNDS with int

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: ERIC’S little face through the back-window of his par car as he watches: ERIC’S POV: the line of MEN’S FACES lining the curved DEP RAMP as the car is about to pull away. Beside his father TAYLOR. His mother, who is driving the car, stares at TAY she starts the car; a look that says something passed bet these two people once that had nothing to do with Harold. As the CAR PULLS AWAY, HAROLD watches ERIC’'S uncomprehen vanishing ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: HAROLD’S FACE reflected on the inside of a PLANE WIND looks out at the high altitude CLOUDS ...  45 HAROLD looks back across the aisle: TAKANE lies back list a Dwight Yokum tape on his WALKMAN. Beside him, JACK METC painstakingly checks through lists of expedition equipmen the window seat in front of JACK sits CLAYBORN in his hal glasses, reading some weighty historical tome, which he a with an expensive propelling pencil. A little further forward, TAYLOR stands in the aisle chat JODI the STEWARDESS; he already has her GIGGLING ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Really -- the point of all this is for the six of us to join the five mile high club. (JODI GIGGLES AGAIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a member?

dialogues.speaker: JODI
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Come on — you can tell me.

dialogues.speaker: JODI
dialogues.text: I did. I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Well -- wanna do something about it? Now JODI is a brave girl, but not that brave.

dialogues.speaker: JODIE
dialogues.text: You’re too much, you know?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: No - come on! This is first class, isn’t it? Help me out here. CLAYBORN is watching now, thin lipped, when DALLAS comes down the aisTe from the toilets and sees the repulsively TAYLOR on the make. A disapproving iook immediately cloud face, and as he passes TAYLOR, he purposely bumps him har

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Sorry if our mascot is giving you a hard time, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: JODI
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: He gets altitude sickness, see, and he just can’t help himself.  46 While TAYLOR mimes vomiting over DALLAS, and the two men into an angry standoff, JODI takes the chance to slip awa

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Dallas!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Thanks buddy ~- owe you one.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Don’t mention it. As DALLAS goes to slip back into his seat beside CLAYBORN passes behind him, and knocks him so hard that he falls c across their leader, who drops his book on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Will you two knock it off? TAYLOR turns and makes a flamboyantly innocent “Who me?" before collapsing in the aisle seat beside HAROLD.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I thought you were already a member?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You get addicted, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: =_SKARDU, NORTHERN PAKISTAN : DAY oo: 33 The TONS AND TONS OF EQUIPMENT are laid out in brightly~c piles in front of the billboard~signed "K2 MOTEL”. While some of the expedition TEAM MEMBERS work at packing mountain of gear into porter-sized loads, and JACK direct group of PAKISTANIS who load a number of finished packs o heavily-decorated TRUCKS, CLAYBORN counts out sackfuls of denomination.rupee notes. Around them, CROWDS of curious PAKISTANIS mill, the women bright saris. HAROLD hands out handfuls of BIROS to the g SHRIEKING, filthy CHILDREN. We also notice the expedition’s army-attache Liaison Offi MALIK negotiating with the shifty IBRAHIM, the head porte Urdu-Balti translator (sirdar). Beyond this hectic scene: the long valley, entirely ringe outlying white~capped peaks of the Karakoram, is also whi it is the whiteness of sand, not snow. The effect is very and very beautiful.  47 34 i EXT/INT : KARAKORAM HIGHWAY : DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MINI-BUSES and FOUR garishly-~painted TRUCKS, top~hea their loads of freight, groan s-l-o-w-l-~y up a very bad beautiful mountain valley ... Blaring Pakistani POP MUSIC, the convoy passes a SIGN whi

dialogues.speaker: "KARAKORAM HIGHWAY."
dialogues.text: IN THE CABIN OF ONE OF THE BUSES: HAROLD, trying to hold CAMERA steady, is squashed between MALIK & the DRIVER, wh smokes filthy K2 cigarettes. As they plough through anoth shaking pothole, HAROLD looks out the window ~ to see a l roadside BILLBOARD advertising Coca Cola. It says: "Have

dialogues.speaker: AM HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: The convoy makes its way carefully over a wooden SUSPENSI BRIDGE. Far below: a rock-strewn RIVER. TAYLOR rides for a change on top of one of the lorry load with several PAKISTANI HITCH~HIKERS, who pass around a ch As his lorry passes over the bridge and turns up yet anot steep incline, it passes another BILLBOARD stating: "The Finger of Death Points at the Speed King."

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON 36
dialogues.text: Ringed by very high snow-capped peaks, DASSO is the end o road: literally as far as the vehicles can go. As the CON enters the picturesque but desperately poor village made brick and thatch, all the VILLAGERS - gap-toothed, bare-f veiled women and filthy naked children - turn out to line read and stare at the strangers. The village is surrounde vivid green agricultural terraces, ploughed by Yaks and w the harsh terrain by generations of skilled hard labor. The CONVOY lurches towards a large flat area just beyond village, where hundreds of local MEN & BOYS gather around small open FIRES. They look up expectantly as the vehicle hundred yards away.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Our porters! MALIK SHOUTS something to the driver and points ....  48 The SIX EXPEDITION VEHICLES form a circle, wagon-train st a flat area of ground near the porters’ camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The climbers’ camp established, CLAYBORN, MALIK & IBRAHIM a noisy negotiation with representatives of the PORTERS, of whom take the opportunity to pray; hundreds of them kn the dust facing Mecca. TAYLOR finds a FRISBEE in his pack, and tosses it to HARO in turn tosses it to TAKANE, who tries an ambitious blind DALLAS. This eludes him, arcing around to hit one of the PORTERS on the bottom; the astonished man leaps up in ala though Allah himself had kicked his ass. Other porters ho LAUGHTER, one of them grabs the fluorescent disk, and soo is a full-on East-West frisbee free-for-all in the dusty Meanwhile: CLAYBORN is still negotiating. He speaks to MA about their sirdar IBRAHIM, who cannot understand English

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Ask him if this deal is going to stick? MALIK & IBRAHIM have a brief exchange in URDU.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Yes, yes - he says no problem.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Tell him there better not be. MALIK MUTTERS something ...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Tell him if there’s a strike he will not get paid. o- (MALIK HESITATES) Go on ~— tell him! MALIK MUTTERS again unconvincingly & then IBRAHIM nods an withdraws ...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: He’s the best sirdar you could find?

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Yes sir!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: T don't trust him.  49

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: He is very well respected by the men here.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Just as long as he understands that he’s working for us and not them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE of the three day march between DASSO & ASKOLE - t inhabited place before the mountain. we see the whole pro of two hundred men strung out along precarious mountain p fording raging streams, hiking through driving rain, and through ever—poorer and smaller villages. In one VILLAGE we see HAROLD acting as team doctor, inspe and dispensing colored pills to a long queue of poorly-no and even deformed VILLAGERS. We also see a bitter mute ar between CLAYBORN, MALIK, IBRAHIM and a number of the PORT On one long ascent we get a hint of competitiveness betwe DALLAS & TAYLOR about their respective hiking speeds; the clearly see themselves as the two lead climbers of the pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HING ASKOLE : EVENING 000000 it 39 The last majestic slope up into ASKOLE, another timeless VILLAGE surrounded by emeraid terraces and soaring white THE TWO HUNDRED PORTERS make a long weary line as they hu towards the evening's camp ... TAYLOR slips past the shattered HAROLD on the trail, thei towering over their heads ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: How you feeling H?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I’ll sleep tonight man, I'll tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Acclimatizing okay?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Is it good news or bad news when you bleed from the ears? Up ahead, ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF ASKOLE, the lead PORTERS st either side of the trail to watch another, descending EXP  50 We hear CLINKING of karabiners and crampons as HAROLD and push their way to the front of the SILENT CROWD ... The DESCENDING EXPEDITION is a SIX-MAN GERMAN CLIMBING PA They are accompanied by a small group of BALTI PORTERS, f whom carry a STRING BED, on which is the body of ANOTHER Bringing up the rear is a pretty, distracted~looking youn ITALIAN WOMAN. They all look like they've been through he While the AMERICANS break through the crowd, and collect the strangers, the PORTERS put the BED down in the middle trail, and the YOUNG WOMAN immediately sits on it and str sick man’s forehead.

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Helmut Steiner -- we're just from Mustagh Tower ~~- the weather was too bad. We had to come down very quickly. (SMILING WEAKLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any food you could spare? While CLAYBORN nods ‘of course’, HAROLD looks at the sick moves forward, and squats down to check on his condition. checks the man’s pulse, eyes etc, and while the woman con to MURMUR to her husband in Italian, withdraws to the mai

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He’s dead!

dialogues.speaker: STEINER
dialogues.text: Her brother too, but she won't believe it. They were climbing on Paiyu. We try to bury him, but she doesn’t agree. They all watch the young widow grieving in her own way as last LIGHT FADES from the surrounding snowcaps 40_: INT + LAMBARDAR’S HOUSE - ASKOLE : EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The village headman’s house is larger, but by no means mo luxurious than the other mud and thatch hovels in Askole. MEMBERS OF BOTH CLIMBING PARTIES, plus MALIK & IBRAHIM, a gathered in the main room, where they play nervously with guest-sized cups of oily yak—-butter tea. HAROLD, almost at the back of the group, looks down a hug in the middle of the floor through which thick SMOKE bill In the sulphurous gloom below them, HAROLD is amazed to s WOMEN, CHILDREN & ANIMALS moving around a cooking fire.  51 Behind HAROLD, next to the main entrance, TAYLOR chats qu and respectfully - in ITALIAN ~- with the teary young WOM Back in the main group: the diplomatic DALLAS is doing be all with the revolting yak-butter cocktails when he spots apparently woolfing the widow, and subtly draws CLAYBORN’ attention to it. He then makes a derogatory comment to TA TAYLOR notices this bait, but continues to talk to the WO exactly the same manner, even going so far as to touch he in a gesture of sympathy. DALLAS takes a step forward, and makes another comment, s inaudible. TAYLOR continues to ignore him; now the grievi is swooning provocatively on his shoulder. CLAYBORN watches the prelude to the shootout nervously, b LAMBARDAR has him well and truly boxed in; he only gets t party once a year, and he intends to make the most of it. Then DALLAS ~ who affects the code of conduct of a Southe Gentleman circa Scarlett O’Hara and thinks he knows a cad sees one ~ can stand it no longer:

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Taylor! TAYLOR nods "a moment please" - in fact he has been condu himself with perfect Etruscan decorum ~ excuses himself f with a soft, familiar PHRASE, and goes to meet his match.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think you’re doing?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’m talking to Signora Giustetta.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: You’re scum! TAYLOR looks back at the WOMAN, and remembers his best be

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: My mother comes from her city.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: (STEPPING CLOSER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a twisted low-~life pervert.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I take that as a compliment?  52

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: What's "five mile high club" in Italian?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What is this? Harvard Trivial Pursuits?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: She’s pregnant, right? That’s your thing ~ pregnant widows! TAYLOR looks again at SIGNORA GIUSTETTA, then politely be DALLAS over as if to talk to her. When DALLAS buys it and up, TAYLOR instead grabs him and pulls him straight throu open doorway and into the village street. CLAYBORN notices all this and signals diplomatic alarm. T intercepts the signal and is the first to move ... 41_: EXT +: LAMBARDAR’S HOUS TAYLOR & DALLAS wrestling seriously. Now Dallas is no pus he has the physical pedigree of a well-bred Ivy League qu back, and is almost as strong as Taylor. Nevertheless, TAYLOR had the element of surprise, and is mooshing his enemy’s face into the dust. He hisses into h

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’tl tell you what my thing is, Woolf. My thing is to climb this fucking mountain. If you’re on my rope while I’m doing it, I'll fight for your life. But I hope one day you’re not on my rope, and you fail off the fucking mountain. ‘Cos when you do, I’1ll be there Woolf, and my thing at that point will be absolutely for fuckun’ definite to piss on your grave. Now TAKANE is at hand, hauling TAYLOR off; CLAYBORN arriv

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: You idiots! The LAMBARDAR and the BALTI VILLAGERS look on at this fas floorshow, and wonder what these strange visitors will ge next? The OTHER CLIMBERS gather too, and while TAKANE continues the TWO panting MEN apart, CLAYBORN reads them the riot a  53

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: One more of those, and you'll both spend the rest of the trip packhorsing. If you can’t behave like men, I’1l treat you like animals. We’re here - this is it! From now on we’re a team, we've got to be! Anybody not in the team, is a danger to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pen EA CRUNCH! A cramponned CLIMBING BOOT stomps on the thin cru that covers a CREVASSE on the glacier. As the icy surface shatters, we see the black hole of the chasm yawning belo

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Jesus! Big one here. TAKANE turns around to warn the rest of the men on his ro an ever-vaster landscape of snow and rock, the expedition together in teams of five or ten for safety - snakes its the frozen river of ice towards its goal. Each of the climbers leads one of the roped groups. We se CLAYBORN - first among equais - striding out in front of party, urging them to make more than their naturai pace. him, TAKANE & DALLAS seem to be in competition; everyone to impress with his fitness and determination in order to maximize his chances of being chosen for the summit team. even MALIK harbors summit ambitions? TAYLOR & HAROLD urge their respective teams along in para ignoring MUMBLES of protest from the PORTERS struggling a behind. Suddenly one of HAROLD'S TEAM stumbles and falls, causing crocodile to grind to a confused halt. TAYLOR ignores the down and presses on relentlessly ...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hey! What's the big hurry?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Devil takes the hindmost, boyo.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Catch up! TAYLOR sees DALLAS turn to check on their relative positi the pecking order, and SHOUTS at his men to go even faste  54

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Christ! HAROLD bullies his team to pull themselves together, take breath, and finally sets off in pursuit. 43_: EXT i CAMPSITE ON THE BALTORO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As COOKING FIRES glow on the moonlit glacier, the AMERICA the chance to chat by their fire or write in their journa TAKANE, who has brought small SPEAKERS for his Profession MAN, explains the words of a favorite C & W song to MALIK CLAYBORN watches TAYLOR pass a cup of coffee to DALLAS; t rivals now maintain an icy detachment from each other. JA recounting some epic alpine adventure to no one in partic While the STARS twinkle in the brilliant sky above, every looks exhausted but happy. Life is good; this is what it’ about. TAYLOR looks at HAROLD, who gvins, before jotting something else in his journal. HAROLD is left~handed; his RING flashes in the fire-light while he writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER MONTAGE: as the expedition slowly wends its way t the upper reaches of the Baltoro glacier, past minor KARA PEAKS — PAIYU, TRAGO ET AL - the landscape becomes ever v bleaker and more inhospitable. As evening approaches, a STORM is brewing. CLAYBORN liste the RADIO for the WEATHER REPORT from Dasso; the news doe sound good, and visibility is becoming poor ~ none of the mountains can be seen,

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: How far to Concordia?

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: _ Two hours?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Think we’ll make it before this storm hits?

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: This is not a good place to camp I think.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Come on ~ let’s go for it! TAKANE & HAROLD nod their agreement, while the contrary D sulks. CLAYBORN considers ~~- and then tugs his protestin of PORTERS forward into the gathering storm,  145

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party struggles to erect their tents in the teeth of gale. Visibility is close to zero; they could be anywhere The utterly exhausted PORTERS drop their loads in piles a to arrange their more rudimentary shelters HAROLD & TAYLOR finally get their tent to work and stumbl it, zipping it up immediately after them. 46_: INT : HAROLD & TAYLOR’S TENT ~ CONCORDIA : NIGHT =: As they struggle in the confined space to organize their light the GASLAMP, extract their sleeping bags, get the S going for something hot to drink, they have to SHOUT to b over the storm. They are both whacked. LATER: they sit snug in their sleeping bags, reading. We STORM continuing outside. HAROLD notices that TAYLOR is r "The Art of War" by Sun Tzu: Confucius meets Machiavelli.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I never read that.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (HOLDING UP THE BOOK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s good on strategy. "When you will survive if you fight quickly, and perish if you do not, this is called ‘dying ground’". TAYLOR passes the book to HAROLD, who scans it, READING:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: "People on dying ground are, as it were, sitting in a leaking boat, lying in a burning house." HAROLD listens to the fierce WIND roaring across the tent

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You got your strategy figured out, H?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I dunno -— What do you mean? (HANDING THE BOOK BACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s your strategy?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Mine is mine. Question is -- what’s yours? No one else can climb the mountain for you, H.  56

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I know that! What are you trying to say? It’s every man for himself from here on in?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: If it comes to that, you've got to be able to deal with it, sure.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Any rules at all? Would you draw the line at say -~ eating human flesh? Mine for instance?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Anything can happen up here H, You can’t rely on anybody but yourself. That’s all I’m trying to say. HAROLD looks thoughtful, even a little troubled, as he tu from TAYLOR and listens to the gale. FADE TO BLACK --~ TAYLOR opens his eyes. The storm has died, and the terrib of the wind is replaced with ... total silence. Then he n that the tent is buried by a snowdrift; the ceiling sags and the light is diminished.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: H! We're snowed in. But HAROLD’s sleeping bag is empty. TAYLOR drags off his starts to find his outer clothes, boots etc ... When he’s dressed, TAYLOR is about to start burrowing his through the snowdrift when HAROLD sticks his head into th tunnel:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Taylor!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Nothing’s the matter. Close your eyes!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Close your eyes!  57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAYLOR stumbles out of their buried tent into the deep po snow and a sparkling, bright blue dawn. HAROLD points him particular direction ...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay - open your eyes. CU: TAYLOR’S FACE, as he opens his eyes - to be confronte most impressive collection of mountains anywhere on earth camp at Concordia is at the confluence of two mighty glac these two monstrous rivers of ice are effortlessly domina this point by Broad Peak, Mitre Peak, Mustagh Tower, plus four Gasherbrums and their satellites. Now TAYLOR turns to the left, and looks up the Godwin Aus GLACIER, where he sees a new mountain of truly appalling Its beautifuliy proportioned pyramid fills the whole end valley, and even at this most spectacular place on earth, is simply nothing else to look at.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Fuck me! The others stamp around pointing out the glistening peaks other. They all know unequivocally in this instant why th here. This is Real Life, and everything else pales in com

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Everybody feeling all right? (EVERYBODY IS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good - because there’s no reason why we shouldn’t make Base Camp tonight. No good reason that is. Some of them-LAUGH, but just now there are restive SHOUTS the PORTERS’ CAMP in the background, and as MALIK comes r up, the LAUGHTER instantly dies away.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Mr Clayborn -- Mr Clayborn -~

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: The porters will not walk on the glacier. It is too dangerous. They say they ~- TAYLOR makes to stand up; CLAYBORN orders him to sit agai  58

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: i_SAY every man who finishes the trip with us will get an extra twenty rupees per day for this part of the glacier. Is that clear? This section only. We leave in ten minutes!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Those fuckers!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Come on everybody. Last day. Then we’re on the mountain. The AMERICANS struggle into their packs for the last stag walk-in; TAYLOR claps HAROLD on the back ~ and quietly po CLAYBORN taking a sustaining hit of oxygen. WHISPERING:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: How long’s he gonna STAY on the mountain, he’s sucking on the 0-2 already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expedition is strung out in a long line with the AMER the front. Suddenly the BALTIS start to knot up and slow and IBRAHIM - who as usual is the only one not carrying a at all - runs forward to find MALIK. And then MALIK strug back up the line to find CLAYBORN. The Liaison Officer's expression says it all ...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: They want to rest.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: For ~-- the rest of the day.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: They want to make camp here.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: We’ve only been going two hours!  59

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: They say it’s too dangerous. Deep snow ~~ many crevasses --

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: What will camping here prove?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: It’ll prove that they get an extra day’s pay.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: We’re going on to Base Camp to~ night. Otherwise no one gets paid.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: They will not move Sahib.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: We'll see about that. CLAYBORN, followed by TAYLOR, DALLAS & MALIK, move down t to have it out with the ringleaders ... They are confronted by an angry, menacing MOB, who wave s and seem in no way intimidated by the white mens’ status employers. After much pushing, shoving and SHOUTING, a lo which is done by TAYLOR, one of the BALTIS actually throw punch, which momentarily decks TAYLOR.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: The ego has landed! Stung as much by this comment as by the blow, TAYLOR leap feet and fights his way back to the particular PACK where stash of RUPEES is hidden. Returning to the fray, TAYLOR grabs out a fistful of the denomination BANKNOTES, and right under the horrified nos the BALTI RINGLEADERS, sets fire to the money.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Tell them they don’t want the money we've already agreed on, I’il burn the fucking lot. Tell them that!

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Stop! You must not do this!! But it’s too late, and the SHRIEKING BALTIS shrink back f appalling act, which clearly establishes TAYLOR as a dang lunatic.  60

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Ten bucks worth ~~ big deal!

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Ten dollars will feed one of their families for six months!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: That’s what I call cost-effective.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: You do not negotiate with them by destroying what they do not have.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You know a better way? So far i haven't seen it, TAYLOR holds the BAG OF MONEY high for all to see and for the front of the line ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Come and get it before it’s too late. The expressions on the faces tell us that TAYLOR has won round but not the fight. We also see that MALIK remains a appalled and insulted as the Baltis at what Taylor has do 30_:_EXT_: ICE FALL - GODWIN AUSTEN GLACIER : DAY _ i

HAROLD'S GROUP has followed DALLAS’ GROUP across an ICE BRIDGE over a huge C in the glacier, when HAROLD looks back to the NEXT GROUP. led by MALIK, who makes the mistake of looking into the a freezes in the middle of the bridge. Calling forward to D

dialogues.text: (DALLAS TURNS AROUND)

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Yeah - okay. HAROLD detaches himself from his group of PORTERS and att them to the end of DALLAS’ group, before turning back to stranded group. MALIK is still paralysed by fear ~ the cr appears to be hundreds of feet deep ~ when there is sudde great splintering SOUND --~ and the BRIDGE begins to coll MALIK miraculously finds his feet again ~~~  61 MALIK runs towards HAROLD'S side of the bridge, leaps the few feet, lands on his belly, and slams his AXE into the classic "safety" ... moments before the PORTERS on the ot of the rope disappear SCREAMING into the crevasse ... We see the incredible strain on MALIK'S face - and we als the strain on the AXE with the weight of the others on it begins to cut a path through the ice... While HAROLD is sprinting back towards MALIK ... DALLAS, TAKANE are untying from their groups and running back too Fractions of a second before MALIK slips over the edge to certain death, HAROLD reaches him, slams the heels of his crampons into the ice, grabs the top of MALIK’S AXE, and back in a seated belay. He manages to postpone the traged then the AXE starts to cut through the ice again. Moments both of them are pulled over the edge ... DALLAS clips a rope through MALIK’S HARNESS, then SCREAMS TAYLOR & TAKANE who are bringing up the rear:

dialogues.speaker: SAFETY
dialogues.text: TAYLOR & TAKANE immediately loop the rope around their ax drive them into the ice, and fall on them in the “safety” position. DALLAS races back from the edge and does the sa

dialogues.text: (TO HAROLD)

dialogues.speaker: LET GO
dialogues.text: HAROLD releases _the axe ~ and MALIK SCREAMS as he drops edge of the crevasse. The rope, held by DALLAS, TAYLOR & snaps taught ... and holds! MALIK'S POV: the OTHER PORTERS dangling SCREAMING below h the black, bottomless crevasse. As CLAYBORN, JACK and groups of the other PORTERS arrive, help haul the line of PORTERS out of the abyss, into whic of the other BALTIS stare, mesmerized. Finally, all the m safely back on firm ice, very glad to be alive. Everyone gathers around to slap the hard~-breathing HAROLD on the they all share a moment of elation. Harold has done it ag

dialogues.text: Deja vu, huh!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s becoming a regular Saint fuckun’ Christopher.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It’s nothing - forget it.  Groups of 62

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: My wife and son will not forget it. You will be their hero - always!

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Did you see the way the axe was just slicing through the ice?! PORTERS are already filing away and standing round in whispering groups, making no sign of re~shouldering their

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We camping here or what? CLAYBORN surveys the PORTERS actions and mood, and decide maybe they have all had enough for one day after all.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Yes -~ we camp here. The CLIMBERS look frustrated at yet another annoying dela

dialogues.text: Congratulations Tarantino. After this is over I’1l nominate you as US Ambassador to Pakistan.

dialogues.text: You wanna go down that crevasse too?

dialogues.text: (MOVING IN QUICKLY)

dialogues.text: Stop it, or you’ll both go down the crevasse. Now get the tents up. Late at night, reading. TAYLOR is still with "The Art of

dialogues.text: So what’s it feel like being the big hero?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It feels good - it feels -- God! That moment was worth my whole lifetime! I did something real for once, something powerful, you know? 1, Harold Jamison, had a measurable effect on human lives! I feel -~ in control -- like I can do anything I want. I feel -~ (JOKE) like I think you must feel all the time Taylor.  63

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Nothing like a little catastrophe to start the heart, huh? TAYLOR smiles at his friend, and reads from the book:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: “Confront them with annihilation, and they will then survive; plunge them into a deadly situation, and they will then live. When people fall into danger, they are then able to strive for victory."

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Victory! HAROLD shoots out his right hand, and they do their hands

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Victory! TAYLOR turns off the GAS LAMP, and we watch the MANTLE di white to black ... 52_i_EXT : THE GLACIER : DAWN 0000 52 The SUN climbs over the peaks on the Eastern edge of the and paints the immense snowscape pink. TAYLOR emerges from his tent, and looks away over towards edge of the glacier, to where TAKANE is digging a hole in thin ice. He walks over, as TAKANE strips off ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Just my little Samurai number. Last day before the mountain. TAYLOR watches astonished as the naked TAKANE lowers hims deep into the freezing water.

dialogues.text: How long you stay in there?

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: (THROUGH WILDLY CHATTERING TEETH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as I can stand it. Constitutionally unable to resist a challenge, now TAYLOR to strip off then piunges - naked and SCREAMING his warcr the water beside the strong-willed Japanese.  64 Now DALLAS emerges from his tent, and stares at this curi competitive spectacle. TAYLOR stares back at his enemy, d him to join them.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Coming in Woolf? DALLAS continues to stare - but then he turns away, as if listening to some disturbing SOUND. TAYLOR & TAKANE continue to stare at each other, each des willing himself to survive the longer in the freezing wat they hear CLAYBORN SHOUTING BACK AT THE TENT: HAROLD is just emerging when he hears t SHOUTING too, and hurries towards the voices ... HAROLD looks back down the glacier towards Concordia - to large groups of PORTERS, many of them carrying their pack FOOD, heading for home. While MALIK dogs the heeis of one SHOUTING, IBRAHIM is running around ARGUING too, and look worried. Meanwhile more and more PORTERS are dumping thei and moving off. HAROLD pursues the leaders, passing CLAYBORN ~ who looks distracted and even defeated,

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hey! Where are you going? Come back! (CATCHING UP TO MALIK)

dialogues.text: What’s happening? Where are they going?

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Home. They will not go on.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But they have to! We're only four hours from Base Camp! MALIK just shrugs and darts ahead to try to sway another leaders. Meanwhile HAROLD spots one of the men he saved f crevasse. Seizing his arm:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? Just a few more hours and we’re there! There is a hint of recognition, and even regret in the PO EYES - but he nevertheless pulls away and keeps walking. tugs at his sleeve and keeps TALKING to him —~ the porter understand a word of English - but the plea has no effect ever, and HAROLD is reduced to standing on the glacier wa the disgruntled, deserting men streaming all around him..  65 BACK IN THE ICE-WATER BATH: Even in this emergency, TAYLO pride forces him to wait for TAKANE to get out first ... And then the TWO PINK~FLUSHED, NAKED MEN race across the to find out what’s going on ... but they are too late. They arrive to see that the dispirited HAROLD, MALIK & IB are already returning to CAMP - without the porters. Abou ninety-five percent of the Baltis have left, leaving PACK in piles all over the ice. TAKANE & TAYLOR are still nake shivering, a sight that DALLAS finds extremely distastefu

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Fuck it! We take it up ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Fourteen tons of it?!? Is this before or after you get dressed?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, cowboy? I thought you ate bobcats for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: I’m talking about time, asshole. It’1l take us maybe two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: He’s right. We’11 be cutting it close with the weather, this late in the season.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: So? We take less. Cut down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7” What are you talking about? We need everything - that’s why we brought it.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: People have climbed this baby with a whole lot less than fourteen tons of gear, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: But ---

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Aw well then - hey fellas — why don’t we just quit, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: C’mon! They're doing us a favor. We don’t need all this crap. (PLEADING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we need is to be a TEAM, right? He’s right. CLAYBORN finally nods

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Taylor and Takane ~ you come with me and Jack to break up the gear. Dallas - you strike camp. Harold ~ you organize the porters who are still here. Any questions? (THERE ARE NONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! Let’s do it! 53_i EXT i BASE CAMP SET-UP MONTAGE : DAY : 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the next two or three days, in variable weather, t CLIMBERS and remaining PORTERS - even the lazy IBRAHIM ca light loads -~ struggle to transport the reduced equipmen from the glacier to the foot of the mist~blown mountain. BASE CAMP is finally established at the foot of K2 - a se colorful TENTS dotted about on the glacier just beyond th avalanche zone - and in the process we see the climbers b work as a real team for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD takes a PHOTOGRAPH of the memorial to the many cli who have died on K2: a stone CAIRN festooned with saucepa tin box lids with inscriptions beaten into them.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/O
dialogues.text: Coming H? HAROLD hurries across to where the rest of the party are up and making ready to move up the mountain. JACK & MALIK listening to the weather report from Dasso on the radio

dialogues.speaker: JACK,
dialogues.text: They give us two days of clear weather. CLAYBORN points to a basic DIAGRAM of the mountain spread the snow. He traces a line up the center: the “magic line then he takes another hit of oxygen; once again HAROLD ex a look with TAYLOR.  67

dialogues.text: All right ~ I want to have Camp One stocked by then, and ropes laid to Camp Two -—-~

dialogues.text: (POINTING ON THE MAP)

dialogues.text: I favor fixed ropes all the way to the summit, but we’1l see how we go with the weather. WHOOMP! A huge AVALANCHE crashes down onto the glacier cl where they stand. The few remaining PORTERS shift uneasil

dialogues.text: The mountain is waking up.

dialogues.text: Take off your wedding ring H.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Because if you get frostbite, your fingers’11 swell, and it’1l give you gangrene.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Love kills, baby. HAROLD takes off his gloves, strings his WEDDING RING aro neck, and puts his gloves back on.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: You take lead on the first rope Dallas. Taylor, you take the second, Questions? HAROLD is looking up at THE SUMMIT looming straight above The faceted sheer walls of ice and granite glint in the s

dialogues.text: Yeah! We all get an equal shot at the summit, right?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Based on fitness ~ right!

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Do you get yours before or after you piss on my grave?  68

dialogues.text: Come on fellas! Team!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Let’s got

dialogues.text: ea SS We see the various ROPED PAIRS of climbers negotiating th Negretto Col on the South South West Ridge. DALLAS & TAKA the lead team set the ice screws, TAYLOR & HAROLD come be laying the fixed ropes, and behind them CLAYBORN, JACK, M the OTHER PORTERS ferry loads. We watch them pass us at a certain point; so far they all be working well, although already the altitude (20,000') making every movement an effort. 56: EXT : CAMP ONE _: DAY. i_56

dialogues.text: DALLAS & TAKANE reach an area of flattened ridge, look at other, nod "perfect", and dump their PACKS. While they lo the astonishing view - from here they can see all the way down the glacier to the CONCORDIA CAMP - the next pairing TAYLOR & HAROLD heave themselves up the last slope to Cam

dialogues.text: Clayborn'’s struggling a bit.

dialogues.text: He always takes a few days to acclimatize. He’1l be okay. TAKANE is already putting on the STOVE to melt some snow drinks ... And by the time CLAYBORN & JACK haul themselves up to the the drinks are ready; TAKANE passes them around, but HARO refuses his. Everybody turns on him in unison:  69

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY
dialogues.text: Drink!

dialogues.text: Dehydration’s the real killer over 20,000’ Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (TAKING THE DRINK)

dialogues.text: Welcome to the Death Zone. CLAYBORN is resting with his head on his pack; he looks w Meanwhile JACK is on the RADIO...

dialogues.text: We've made good time.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Weather’s holding.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: I’m all right goddammit! I can pull my weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: DAWN 8B
dialogues.text: Leaving the tents erect, the CLIMBERS have finished break are about to set off on the day’s haulage work. While CLA JACK & MALIK prepare to descend for more gear, the OTHERS heading higher to lay ropes to Camp Two and beyond.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: We’ll meet at Camp Two for supper.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We could come back down here if --  70

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: No need! Camp Two. Good luck. CLAYBORN, JACK ET AL turn and using the fixed ropes, lowe themselves over the edge for the downward journey. Meanwh OTHER FOUR prepare to head up.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: (TO TAKANE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to lead today?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: i want to lead today. DALLAS looks at TAYLOR then at TAKANE ~ and then up the m Immediately above them, a vertical ICE CHIMNEY stretches hundred feet, after which it appears to plateau out. Chec that CLAYBORN is out of sight:

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: First one to the top leads today. TAYLOR grins, HAROLD gulps ... and before anyone has more think about it, they are all four of them hacking up the in a frenzy of axes, crampons and flying ice.

dialogues.text: Before we can see the climbers we can HEAR their approach Finally an ice axe and ice hammer stab into the lip of th followed immediately by two more sets of axes and hammers climber belonging to the first set pops his head over the is TAYLOR. While he hauis himself over the lip, DALLAS & heads appear, and moments later, HAROLD'S. TAYLOR, absolutely shattered by his effort, lies out full on his back on the ice, while the others clamber up behin equally exhausted, HAROLD collapses beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the OTHERS prepare the next upward LOADS, CLAYBORN collapsed in a chair, gasping oxygen. JACK looks concerne when CLAYBORN catches the look, he puts the BREATHING APP away and rejoins the work.  71 61_:_ EXT : CAMP TWO : DAY i 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With TAYLOR leading, the FOUR CLIMBERS arrive at the slig less than sheer incline that will be Camp Two. The VIEW i more extraordinary, although only TAYLOR has eyes for it; others are too wrecked. TAYLOR breaks out the TWO-WAY RAD

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Camp Two to Base. Come in Base ~-- you read me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK hears the SQUELCH on the RADIO, and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hey! Taylor! Base reading you!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/0
dialogues.text: We’re ready for you here. Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Roger - we’re just setting off. TAYLOR standing; the OTHERS lying:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We're going to push on up to Camp Three. (GROANS FROM THE OTHER THREE) See you back here for supper. Over.

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: Roger. Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jesus! What are you trying to do to us?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Whatsamatter guys?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think I just fucking died, that’s what’s the matter!

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: I KNOW I did.  72

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You guys stay here and rest. I’1l lay the ropes to Three by myself.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: I’m coming with you. But we gotta have a drink first. TAYLOR looks at DALLAS; he looks as wasted as the other t he is not about to let TAYLOR get the idea that he is top A WHILE LATER: DALLAS & TAYLOR put down their cups, and r together. DALLAS is about to move off in the lead, coils over both shoulders, when TAYLOR light~heartedly pulls hi

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Thought I was climbing lead today? DALLAS shrugs “oh yeah -~ forgot", and steps aside to let make the first move across a difficult face of icy granit 64: EXT : CAMP TWO i: EVENING ee 4 By the time TAYLOR & DALLAS make their way back down to C TAKANE & HAROLD have set up camp on the narrow ledge, and weather is closing in. TAKANE hands the two climbers hot

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Storm coming in. Otherwise we’re in great shape.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Heard from the others?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: They'il be here any minute. TAYLOR looks over the edge to where: Five hundred feet be Two, the heavily-laden CLAYBORN, JACK & MALIK are hauling selves very slowly up the rope. Then CLOUDS blow across t mountain, obliterating the climbers.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Everything go okay? TAYLOR turns and nods nonchalantly, but DALLAS doesn’t re HAROLD cannot tell whether it is from exhaustion or disda wonders what passed between the two men when they were al the mountain. The wind is getting stronger every moment.  73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LIGHTS from the three tiny tents squeezed onto the in ledge are barely visible through the storm-driven cloud a While the LAMP splutters and the tent heaves in the wind, & TAYLOR talk before going to sleep:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How did you go with Dallas today?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Come on - what happened?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Something must have. I mean —~

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We laid rope. I led most of the day. He didn’t say a word.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Not one?!!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (SHAKES HIS HEAD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s quite strong ---

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: a What do you think about when you’re climbing?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Sex.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sex you’ve had, or sex you’re going to have?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Sex I didn’t have. I think about the ones that got away.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You mean there were some?!?  74

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Cindy. I never had Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thanks very much!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: No ~ there was a moment there ~ when you first met her ~ she -~

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: She what? You mean you jerk yourself off on mountains thinking about my wife?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Never mind. You asked me.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You’re fucking serious, aren’t you? You get me up here --— But this fascinating conversation is interrupted by TAKAN unzips and bursts into their tent, a furious flurry of SN blowing in with him. As he frantically re-zips the tent:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Clayborn’s sick! Think it’s edema.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NI/EXT i CLAYBORN'’S TENT : NIGHT os 67 HAROLD, TAYLOR, TAKANE, MALIK & JACK squeeze into the tin where CLAYBORN lies in his sleeping bag looking dreadful. lips are blue, his breathing weak and ragged. JACK is tak pulse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don’t feel --~ too good.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You don’t look too good. I mean -~ er --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We’ve got to get you down.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: The storm’11 be over soon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Tonight?!?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We gotta get him as low as possible as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Who’s gonna go with him?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.text: I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: I will go also.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The rest of you wait out the storm here. Let’s do it! JACK is administering oxygen, but CLAYBORN is almost too to breath it in. While all hands urgently strip off their leader’s sleeping bag and help pack the necessary gear .. OUTSIDE THE TENT: DALLAS stands aloof in the storm, waiti the reins of power to fall into his hands,

The storm is slightly easier when JACK & MALIK clip CLAYB the fixed DOWN-ROPE - they all wear LAMPS on their helmet ease him over the edge. JACK & TAKANE test their RADIOS, TAYLOR, HAROLD, TAKANE & DALLAS stand and watch the THREE disappear before scurrying back to their respective tents

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: T usually just take what I want and fuck the consequences H. I didn’t take Cindy, okay?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Who says she’d have wanted you? TAYLOR just smiles and turns off the LIGHT. The WIND rage again outside ...  76

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/O
dialogues.text: Think they'll make it?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD V/0O
dialogues.text: You’re a shit Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The STORM is much easier now, and the FOUR CLIMBERS stand ready to set off back up to Camp Three. DALLAS is on the Base Camp:

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: Patchy. Tomorrow should be better.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Roger. We’re heading up now. We’11 call you from Three.

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Over. The FOUR OF THEM zip up the TENTS, don their extra~heavy and set off up the rope

TAYLOR pauses for a moment and looks up towards the summi A gap in the CLOUDS appears, and the SUMMIT is briefly vi like an Indian arrow head against the troubled sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT i CAMP THREE : DAY _ 172

dialogues.text: The FOUR CLIMBERS pause at the end of the FIXED ROPES — t for CAMP THREE. While the weather looks a little clearer, brews drinks and DALLAS talks to Base:

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
