dialogues.text: Clear as a bell, boy. How you all doing?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: We're all fine. How’s Clayborn?

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: He’s a iittle better. He's sleeping most of the time.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: How's the weather?

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: Reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: We're going to keep on going up to Four. The OTHER THREE look at each other; DALLAS has taken an e decision without consulting them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: What's the big hurry? DALLAS looks back at the others, but despite a few signif looks, none of them choose to dispute the call. ” DALLAS We’ll call you from Four. Over. DALLAS switches off the RADIO, stows it in his pack, and a HOT DRINK from TAKANE.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Hell - why not? We can be on the summit for breakfast. DALLAS looks shifty, while HAROLD strips off a glove to i for frostbite. TAYLOR touches his hot metal mug to one of HAROLD'S bare, white FINGERS ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Can you feel that?  78

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. TAYLOR looks at TAKANE, and minutes later ... HAROLD squats soaking his two bare hands in hot water in COOKING POT. Meanwhile DALLAS is surveying the next pitch

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: We'll take that ridge there, then traverse that wall ~--

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You can traverse it if you like. It looks rotten to me.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: How can you tell from here?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Like I said - you can go that way you want. I’1l take what- ever’s in back of the ridge.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: A team sticks together. TAYLOR looks around for support, but both of the others a gaze. TAYLOR shrugs mock-democratically and looks back up big wall facing them...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Hope you remember that when the shit hits the fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK stares at the mountain through a powerful TELESCOPE tripod, while CLAYBORN dozes beside him in a deckchair, w in his sleeping bag, an OXYGEN CYLINDER on the snow besid JACK turns to say something, but realizes that CLAYBORN i it, then stands back to allow MALIK to look through the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAYLOR climbs across the extremely dangerous wall of blue over granite. He looks down at the OTHER THREE CLIMBERS w on the ledge below, then drives in another ICE SCREW, cli it, and allows it to take his weight. It doesn’t! A huge rotten ice gives way all round where the screw went in, a TAYLOR drops into space.  719

dialogues.speaker: FALLING
dialogues.text: The OTHERS take precautionary tension on the rope as TAYL momentum rips out three other screws before the fourth - ~ holds! TAYLOR ends up dangling limply in space not far the others’ heads. He looks down at them — and smiles iro

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Hey fellas! Guess what? There's some rotten ice up here! TAYLOR'S axe & hammer hang from their wrist straps. He sp the rope, slams the point of his axe into the ice, and pu himself back onto the wall. 2:75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLAYBORN is awake now, and looking slightly better. But h still weak, and can barely stand. JACK is still looking t the telescope ...

dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.text: There! Just below the Mushroom, They’re making real good time,

dialogues.text: (TAKING OFF RADIO HEADPHONES)

dialogues.speaker: MALIK
dialogues.text: Then bad,

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: (LOOKS AT JACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While TAYLOR & a very tired TAKANE struggle with the SECO DALLAS talks on the RADIO to Base; through the open flap FIRST TENT, we see HAROLD stretched out, resting.  80

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: I say we go for it.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN V/O
dialogues.text: You've put in three of four pretty solid days. You sure you can get to the summit and back in twenty-four hours?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: No problem. TAYLOR drops what he’s doing and crawls into his tent wee HAROLD is wrapped in his sleeping bag, dozing.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: H! Wake up! Woolf wants to go for the summit.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Now? Oh man ~- I’m fucked,

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We’re all fucked, but we only got a twenty-four hour weather window.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ohhh -- okay ~- okay. I’m ready.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You sure now? HAROLD initiates the special HANDSHAKE, he hurriedly de-b the two men scramble out of the tent ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAYLOR & HAROLD re-emerge from the tent, to see DALLAS st them.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Take it easy. No hurry.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I thought you said ~~

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: I said "we" are going for the summit. No one said "we" meant all of us.  81

dialogues.text: So what DOES “we" mean?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: It means me -- and Takane,

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute! If it’s only two to the top, you've got to take the best two.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You -- and me.

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Now you wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Tak, but we're talking about going now, Dallas and I are the only two who've got a shot. You stay. HAROLD cannot believe his own ears as his supremely oppor best friend betrays TAYLOR is surprised question. their "us two as a team" trust.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Fuck you Taylor! What is this?

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Takane and I are the summit team. Been that way since before you.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: But you’ve got to take me! I’m the best climber. And I'm the fittest of any of us.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: I'm not taking you. That's that.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Why the hell can’t we all go?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Give me that radio! when DALLAS hands the RADIO over without

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Clayborn? Taylor! We got a little -- diplomatic problem here.  TAYLOR switches off 82

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN V/O
dialogues.text: Well whatever it is, Dallas will have to sort it out.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: No - listen! We had a deal. We all get an equal shot at the summit, based on fitness.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN V/O
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We got four guys here. We all want to go.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN V/O
dialogues.text: Impossible, Two have got to stay back in reserve,

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: But ---

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN V/0O
dialogues.text: Two stay! That’s an order!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Okay -- okay ~- so now the question is which two, right?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN V/O
dialogues.text: Dallas will have to decide.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN V/O
dialogues.text: I can’t decide who goes from down here Taylor. Dallas has my full authority to act for me while I’m out of action. the RADIO in disgust & drops it on the snow.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You are so fuckun’ dumb Woolf.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: We’1l see about that. TAYLOR avoids HAROLD’S glare and turns to look over the p while DALLAS & TAKANE hastily prepare for their summit at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD is still angry with Taylor for having wanted to sa their friendship pact to satisfy his summit ambitions. Ou the wind HOWLS.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Oh come on man - speak to me.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I just can’t believe you would have gone without me.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What if Woolf had chosen you instead of Takane? You’d have gone without me.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No way!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s your problem?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh I get it. We’re on ‘dying ground’ now, & anything goes. What's next on the secret agenda?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (LISTENS TO THE WIND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get our crack at it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don’t trust you any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WIND is getting stronger all the time ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. I am a shit, I am a shit. A hundred times. I am a 100% total shit. (HAROLD SMILES A LITTLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think I want to be around you H? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: At this point I really wouldn’t know,

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Because you’re not a shit.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I’m learning.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Goodnight! HAROLD turns his back on TAYLOR, TAYLOR does the same — a end the scene ignoring each other like a feuding married

The CREAKS and GROANS, and we get the feeling of the utter de of being up there in these conditions. Somewhere on a steep SNOW SLOPE, A MAN’S BODY cartwheels desperately clutching at a trailing, unsecured ROPE. The LAMP is on as the body spins on down the mountain ... 82_:_ INT/EXT_: HAROLD’S & TAYLOR'S TENT ~ CAMP FOUR : NI

dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/O
dialogues.text: Huh? What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD V/0
dialogues.text: Dunno - I thought I heard something ~~ a voice --—  85 And just then ... both TAYLOR & HAROLD SHOUT OUT in alarm BODY crashes into the tent! When they sort themselves out, they discover that the sur visitor is TAKANE - delirious and frozen almost to death. light the LAMP, re-pitch the tent and lay TAKANE out insi Then, while TAYLOR gets the stove going for hot drinks, H does what he can for his fingers, biack with frostbite. F TAKANE has his eyes open and manages to take some liquid.

dialogues.text: (SHAKING HIM)

dialogues.text: Did you make the summit? TAKANE shakes his head. From the look in his eyes, we can his spirit has been broken. The mountain has told him to

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t come down ~-—

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You mean == he was still alive when you left him?!!

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: (NODS HEAD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storm hit ~-- he wanted to wait it out -- he ---

dialogues.text: But you didn’t have a tent!

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: He wanted the mountain so bad.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: ~ And you?

dialogues.speaker: TAKANE
dialogues.text: It was very bad up there --— dark. I can't feel my legs.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Has he still got the radio? TAKANE shrugs, and TAYLOR grabs their RADIO up again

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Dallas! Come in you dumb shit! (SQUELCH --~—) Answer me goddammit! Dallas! Where the hell are you man?  86 TAYLOR puts down the radio and looks at TAKANE, who has d off to sleep in HAROLD’S arms. Outside, the STORM rages h than ever. TAYLOR looks at HAROLD, who shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD wakes first, and listens: the storm has died away. looks across to TAYLOR, who is still asleep. Between them TAKANE, covered with every piece of spare clothing they c find. HAROLD sits up an checks TAKANE’s pulse, then his e

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Taylor!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: WAKE UP
dialogues.text: (TAYLOR OPENS HIS EYES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tak's dead!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: But he was --- oh fuck! Suddenly TAYLOR is out of his sleeping bag and, after a c almost superstitious glance at the corpse, he is unzippin tent. OUTSIDE: there is a miraculous clear, still, blue d

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jesus Taylor! What do we DO?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I don’t know! TAYLOR picks up the RADIO, toys with it, then looks at HA really doesn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: ~ We gotta go look for Dallas, right?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah! Dallas --~ right! You up for that?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I’m up for it. Are you up for it? TAYLOR, who seems uncharacteristically confused by this t nods vaguely and tosses the RADIO to HAROLD ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Here - you talk to them.  87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -&§_TAYLOR’S TENT - CAMP FOUR : DAWN i: 84 TAYLOR & HAROLD stand, heads bowed, for a moment’s silenc snow grave they have dug for TAKANE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In clear weather, TAYLOR & HAROLD search the accessible p the upper mountain. But without any real clues as to wher might be, their chances of finding him - dead or alive - slim. Taylor is back in his single minded warrior mode. They climb free-style - no safety rope ~ up a reasonable chimney until they reach a small plateau above it, from w they can see fairly far around them. No sign of Dallas an

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: He could be anywhere up here.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Dalias!! You reading us? Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Oh man this is pointless.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You think he’s dead?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah - I think he’s dead. Gotta be. Don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jack? Phillip? Anyone awake down there?

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: Reading you Harold. Over.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There’s no sign of him up here. You heard anything?

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/O
dialogues.text: No. Listen - Phillip’s getting worse again. We've got to get him down quick.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How the hell you gonna do that?  88

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/0
dialogues.text: Malik’s trying to get an army chopper to come up for us.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Where does that leave us? JACK Vso A long way from home ~ unless you get your asses down here real quick. The weather’s gonna hold today, but after that I don’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (TO TAYLOR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? HAROLD looks above them ~ to where the SUMMIT glints crys white in the early morning sun. TAYLOR kills the stare at the summit

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We didn’t come up here for nothing! Screw the chopper. We walked in, we can walk out. (GRABBING THE RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? -- Wish us luck. We're going for it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/0
dialogues.text: But -~= radio and slips it into the pack. They both again ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We leave everything here ~ tent, bags ~- travel light -- we can be back here by tonight.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Right! Then ~ bit of luck - we're back at Base by tomorrow night —~-

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: And I bet you the goddam chopper hasn't even arrived by then!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We're going to do it Taylor!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah! Except I thought you said you didn’t trust me any more.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I’m working on it. TAYLOR smiles —- they do their “Victory” handshake ~- the stripping TENTS ETC out of their packs ... CAMP FIVE established HAROLD & TAYLOR, carrying only the minimum equipment necessary for a day's climbing, set off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oe BS While MALIK SHOUTS into the RADIO in Pakistani in the bac JACK looks through the TELESCOPE, and CLAYBORN takes up h position in the chair. He is looking alert, but very ill.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah - I can see them.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: How close are they?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Close enough. They've got a shot at it. CLAYBORN suddenly starts COUGHING desperately - he sees a of BLOOD on his white glove - while MALIK SHOUTS even lou

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. The chopper comes, we’re not waiting. It’s their risk. That’s it. HAROLD’S FACE shows his sheer exhaustion as he drags hims steep but negotiable ICE SLOPE. At this airless altitude, slightest movement is a tremendous act of will, and the w exercise at this point is reduced to brute animal effort. ahead of him, TAYLOR rests, waiting for his buddy to catc looks at his WATCH, then he looks up at the SUMMIT, which look so very far away now. HAROLD collapses beside him.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Come on! Another coupla hours.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oooo have mercy brother!  90

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We left the mercy behind with the gas-powered pitons H. Ain’t no mercy in the Death Zone.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: We rest on the summit.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Right! Rest on the summit! HAROLD rams his face into the snow, gathering the strengt carry on. But first he lets out a desperate, defiant HOWL We watch the TWO COLORED FIGURES dragging themselves over another dangerous ICE CORNICE at somewhere around 28,000 and somehow sense the almost surreal quality of this ridi endeavour; we get the idea of two guys locked into some i self-imposed ritual where a single false move will kill t where the best they can hope for is just to survive, A mere few hundred feet above them, the pristine white SU dazzles in the clear, strong sunlight ... the final slog the summit is not technically difficult, but it definitel presents a challenge to the will. Both men are now at the their reserves of strength, and trudge slow motion up the slope as though they wear lead shoes in some dream, HAROLD pauses and looks at the incredible VIEW; he imagin can see the whole Himalaya laid out around him. Then he l at the SUMMIT just above them ~ and he knows for the firs with certainty that they are going to make it. Just ahead TAYLOR falls to his knees for a moment's respite. HAROLD catches up to him...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: _ Taylor! We’re gonna do it!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah! I know.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Come on! Ten feet more! TAYLOR looks at the supreme sense of accomplishment on HA face, and knows that this is Harold’s Big Moment on the m Harold has transcended himself.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You go on. I just ~--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No! We rest on the summit!
TAYLOR allows HAROLD to haul him to his knees, and they s the last few feet to the SUMMIT, glove in glove, together embrace in exhausted ecstacy and collapse to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh man we did it! We fucking did it!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You did it H. You did it - and no one can ever take it away from you. They stand and turn slowly around, looking at the VIEW. I later in the day than perhaps they had hoped for; the sun already setting behind ANGRY CLOUDS on the Western horizo the windchill factor is high. HAROLD takes out his CAMERA and takes some pictures; then TAYLOR to take several of him mugging at the exact highes of the mountain. Then they prop up the camera on a pack f set the timer release, and take a picture of themselves t While HAROLD, still breathing heavily, continues to be lo wonder, TAYLOR gets out the TWO-WAY RADIO:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Hey! Summit party to Base! You still with us? Jack? The RADIO WHINES and splutters. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/0
dialogues.text: Taylor! Harold! Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: On top of the fucking world. That was the idea wasn’t it? Except -~ we forgot the flag!

dialogues.speaker: JACK V/0
dialogues.text: Congratulations! Hang on ~--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK passes the RADIO to CLAYBORN, still swathed in quilt seated in his deckchair. He COUGHS as he takes the radio.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Taylor? Phillip here. Congratulations!  92

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/O
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s a top spot - view is kinda like the one from your office. How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: I feel like shit. I got to get off this mountain.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/O
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. We heard about the chopper.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: We're hoping tomorrow/day after. Can you be down by tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/O
dialogues.text: We’ll wait here -- send the chopper up for us!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Taylor -~ I have to tell you: I’m dying. If you're not here, it will leave without you.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR V/O
dialogues.text: Whatever. Here ~ speak to Harold.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD V/O
dialogues.text: Phillip! Wish you were here!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: If I was ten years younger I would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No --~ it can happen to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Especially grandfathers. Weil done Harold. Get your ass down here. Move it! He hands the RADIO back to JACK.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And watch the weather you guys. You’re going to have a rough night up there. We’ll keep the line open, you need us.  93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moody SUNSET is rapidly becoming obscured by black cl TAYLOR & HAROLD toast themselves with a hot brew. They se nonchalant, and not in any hurry ~- they are possibly suf little from high altitude “everything is fabulous" euphor

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thinking about the next girl?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’m thinking about the next mountain.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Let's get off this one first. What’s the strategy? As they pack up the STOVE etc and make ready for their de

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: The climb down is always the hardest part, you know? After one last look at the summit, they turn and head on mountain. Somehow they both know that this will be the ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAYLOR & HAROLD are slipping down an ICE SLOPE in the dar BLACK CLOUDS swallow the FULL MOON - and seconds later, t STORM hits! In seconds, visibility is drastically reduced TAYLOR gestures to HAROLD that they should rope up. In th determination to travel light, they have only brought one length of rope between them. When ready, they SHOUT something to each other - the wind it away - and then they continue down. The storm only get They fight their way along a narrow ridge, but the weathe beating them, and it is time to find shelter. Down there? A hundred feet further down, after a life-saving belay by TAYLOR finds a protected bank of snow big enough to allow cave. They move to the face away from the worst of the wi dig into the soft snow frantically with their hands ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheltered by TAYLOR, the STOVE CATCHES ALIGHT. HAROLD sla into their pot, and sets it over the fire to meit; the fl reveal the fear in their faces. HAROLD’S HANDS are shakin  94

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: “Climb her while she sleeps!"

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh huh - and this one’s woken up for a midnight snack. Food! TAYLOR rummages in the pack, but all he comes up with are Trail Mix bars and one pack of dried chicken soup.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Great! I love to travel light!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: This is a picnic! I lost twenty pounds one trip!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You know -~ I’m a bit worried! TAYLOR flicks a look at him as he stirs the snow-soup.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah -- maybe it is shaping up into a bit of an epic. HAROLD grabs the RADIO, SHOUTS into it ... but they get n but STATIC ...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: An epic? It’s already a Near Death Experience!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: This the worst jam you ever been in?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Nothing’s happened yet!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Two guys are dead and ---~ and we’re circling at ten thousand feet over Base Camp in a white-— out with one packet of chicken soup and no landing gear! Want me to go on?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Everything’s cool. We’ll make it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You’re just as scared as I am.  95

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Tf I was IT wouldn’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You don’t have to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Fear is bullshit H. Choke you to death. Ignore it. We’re going to get out of this. This storm’11 be over in a day or two --—

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We’ve got nothing to eat!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Don’t need it. The STOVE SPLUTTERS - and dies.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Or drink. There’s no more fuel! TAYLOR simply huddles himself up nearest the hole and sta into the storm ... TAYLOR looks at his WATCH: 9:37 AM. Twelve hours have pas the TWO MEN have barely moved. The STORM continues unabat HAROLD looks at his WATCH: 4:46 PM. The wind has died rig and although visibility is still poor, weather conditions altogether better.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Let’s go! TAYLOR gestures "okay", and reaches for the RADIO to call

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Hey! Base! Jack! ~-— Fuck!!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Fucking BATTERIES!! TAYLOR hurls the now useless RADIO through the mouth of t and then, without a further word, TAYLOR zips up the PACK they’re out of there ...  96 24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weather is only reasonable, and it is already almost when they come to the top of an ICE CLIFF. HAROLD is the anxious and exhausted of the two, and as soon as they sto moving, his teeth start CHATTERING.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What do you think? You want to bivouac here?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Let’s do it,

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Rope up?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What’s the point? Never get a belay in this ice.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You feeling all right?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Come on Taylor! Let’s just do it, all right? TAYLOR shrugs, and moves to take the lead down the danger Crampons and axes digging desperately into the flaky ice, Follows down just after TAYLOR, who is climbing faster an confidently. HAROLD closes his eyes, breathes hard, and p foot in front of the other. Each step, each movement is a Half-way down, HAROLD looks below, to where TAYLOR is eve further ahead of him than before. Fifty feet below TAYLOR is a narrow snow-covered ledge, and below that, another y drop. The height makes HAROLD momentarily dizzy. TAYLOR looks up:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Okay H?!?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Bad ice here. Keep right! HAROLD yanks out his axe, and stretches to his right, loo purchase in order to change the angle of his descent. His attempt is too weak to penetrate the ice; the second seem hold. He tests his weight on the axe, pulls out his right and stretches it across ...  97 Pinned to the wall by his left boot and his right hand, H has got himself stranded; his free right boot cannot find purchase, and he starts to flail with it TAYLOR looks up, alerted by the shower of ICE CHIPS from And just then HAROLD starts to panic ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Hang on! Coming up! TAYLOR begins to get organized to go back up, when the po HAROLD'S AXE starts to pull out of the ice and ---— HAROLD FALLS! Grazing down the sheer wall of ice, he pass appalled TAYLOR in a blur, and plummets to the SNOW LEDGE Miraculously, HAROLD sticks on the ledge without going ov but then he lies ominously still, one leg at a crazy angl TAYLOR crampons down the ice wall as fast as he possibly TAYLOR turns his friend’s head around --- and finds a new overwhelming fear in HAROLD’S EYES. He also immediately s the extent of Harold's injuries and fails, in the first m that their eyes meet, to disguise his certainty that Haro now doomed to die on the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What is it? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Leg!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (TOUCHING H’S RIGHT LEG) This one? (HAROLD SCREAMS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you bend it? TAYLOR shifts HAROLD’S LEG very slightly; HAROLD SCREAMS

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Broken huh? HAROLD nods his head through the shattering waves of pain gently, TAYLOR opens the sidezip on H’s mountain suit, an fully examines the leg; even through the thermal underwea can tell that the leg is a complete shambles. HAROLD SCRE more during this operation, tears streaming down his face he goes all calm...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Don’t think the bone has come through the skin.  98

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh Cindy -- Cindy -~

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: H! It’s me! I’m here!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't want to die.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Who said anything about that? This is going to mend fine -~ bone heals a whole lot better if the skin isn’t broken, see?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You can make it. You can still make it, but you gotta go now!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I’m going to die, Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You're not going to die!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I can’t walk. You can’t carry me. We haven’t got enough rope to work anything with.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’711 go down and get some.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Taylor -- nobody’s ever got a stretcher case off this mountain from so high up. Never! Not even - with a whole team.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: That’s what I’11 do - I’1l go down and get the other guys.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jack & Malik?!? They’d never make it. They did - I’d be dead by the time they got here anyway. HAROLD fumbles inside his jacket - and pulls out his WEDD RING. He snaps the cord, and hands the ring to TAYLOR.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  99

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Give this to Cindy. Tell her -- God I dunno -- tell her I loved her. And I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Tell her yourself!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Taylor I am dead meat. I cannot move! Now get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’m not going to do that!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You just going to sit here and die with me? Bulishit!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You know what you're asking me to do? Is that your twisted fuckun’ idea of revenge?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No no no no ---

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yes yes yes yes! Every lousy minute of every stinking day! I gotta be the selfish rat fuck who left his noble buddy to die. Well forget it! Not guilty!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You never had a problem with being selfish before Taylor - it’s practically your religion! Why the hell do you have to make such a big deal out of it now?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: WHY? Why do you think I do mountains? Huh? You got the wife and the kid and the nice job in medical research -~~ that’s great ~~ but what have I got? My whole life is about ME, my work is all about saving assholes from jail - so I come to places like this ~ with you ~ to try and find a little grace, you know? I don’t want to be seifish all my life. Baddahhh! Meet the flip side of Taylor Tarantino! I want some nobility god damn it - and you - my very very best friend - want to take that possibility away from me for ever!  100

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You want nobility? You want grace? Go back!

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY TO DIE ON SOME GODDAM MOUNTAIN
dialogues.text: Now HAROLD fumbles in the PACK, and produces his CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You’re really my friend Taylor, that’s exactly what you’ve got to do! I want you to look after my son! I want you to give him these ~ tell him I made it - tell him what a big fucking hero I was. Tell him how {f died, and tell him how much I loved him -~- that’s what I want, and then I'll have it all. We can both have it all Taylor, if you just -- go back. Please ~-~ Their eyes meet for a moment of truth, and then TAYLOR’S straying down the mountain. After a long and silent conve

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You're a prince, H. HAROLD turns his head away, smiling to himself mysterious

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Fuck Prince! You're the born survivor Taylor. That’s what I always admired about you.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Because I’m a ruthless shit you admired me?!!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There’s some destiny thing about single-minded people that us born losers find very compelling.  101

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You are not a loser!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I got everything I wanted — but I had to give up everything to get it. Is that winning? Meanwhile TAYLOR is stripping every superfluous thing he need off his body to reduce the weight; he leaves the PAC HAROLD, and even takes off his WATCH - we see it says: 6: He offers it to HAROLD, who refuses it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How long have I got? TAYLOR sniffs the weather, and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: How long have I got? HAROLD takes off his own WATCH and throws it into the sto lands not far along the ledge. TAYLOR does the same with WATCH, and then they embrace ....

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I love you H.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I know. And teach Eric to climb good, will ya? TAYLOR drives one of his last PITONS into some healthy ic

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I’1l take good care of Eric.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Eric -- and Cindy!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus! Will you stop it!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yeah ~- guess I better. I'll tell you the rest in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You’11l have to write me a letter, ‘’cos I’1ll be in hell. They stares into each others’ eyes for a long, last farew moment, Their eyes mirror each other's pain, but also eac other’s souls; they have at last shared some deep, primal standing. And then TAYLOR drops over the ledge and is gon  102 HAROLD lies back down and watches TAYLOR'S ROPE tense and as he abseils down the face below. Moments later, once TA reached bottom, he releases and pulls the rope down after CU: the end of the rope as it zips through the piton and disappears over the ledge. HAROLD is now totally, utterly alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK enters CLAYBORN'S TENT; the sick man stirs in his sl bag; we see his FROSTY BREATH as thin spindrifts of steam

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Phillip! You awake?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Uh? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Chopper'11 be here tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Thank God! What about Taylor?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Haven't heard anything for over twenty-four hours.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look good I’m afraid. CLAYBORN absorbs this new blow, and simply turns his head 26_i_EXT_i TAYLOR'S DESCENT : NIGHT 8 ts 8G Although a cruel wind whips TAYLOR’S FACE, the sky is at partly clear, and a FULL MOON mocks his efforts to find t line of descent. Starving and totally exhausted, he trips and SWEARS violently as he tumbles down a SNOW SLOPE ... TAYLOR comes to rest and lies still for a moment, staring the MOON. Then his eyes close; it would be so much easier forget the whole thing and just ..,. go to sleep. SNOW bl across his face, flakes already settling in the hollows .  103 O72 EXT} HAROLD’S LEDGE : NIGHT ts HAROLD lies back staring at the MOON, SINGING to himself his mind off his pain, and the hovering prospect of his g death. He stares too at the WATCH, just out of reach alon ledge, which ticks off the remaining minutes of his exist

dialogues.speaker: 9B
dialogues.text: TAYLOR’S EYES pop open; he SHOUTS something to himself, h himself to his feet, and starts slamming one boot in fron other, front-pointing down yet another moonlight-drenched face with alarming bravado. TALKING as if to a woman:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Come on baby! You let me climb up you ~~ let me climb off ya. That’s it -- that’s my girl -~ I wanted you so bad baby ~~ too bad, you know -- and you're the best I ever had -~ so let’s not spoil it now, huh? Qooo00 I can smeli yooooou, you evil fuckun’ bitch ~~ I can’t see you, but I can sure as hell smell you. 29_i EXT: ON THE MOUNTAIN : NIGHT _ ~ ID SNOW blows off a luminous WATCHFACE, which is ona MAN’S W The time is 1:12 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD’S frosted eyes are closed as he lies still. He is SINGING, but--only just, as his teeth are chattering too Nearby, the WATCH continues to count the seconds ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 A beard of CLOUD blows across the FULL MOON as TAYLOR sli down an iced granite face. His face is bleeding, his knee bruised. He lands on an apparent ridge of snow, turns and towards the edge to inspect the drop ... The crust gives way without warning as TAYLOR approaches and he slides over it, slowly at first, as though in a co glide. But then he does gather speed, and he has no contr whatsoever. At one moment he is falling freely through sp  104 And then his fall is abruptly broken! He lies very still snow, his eyes closed. A SNOWFLAKE staunches the fresh BL his face ... TAYLOR’S HAND grips the ROPE that broke his fall. His fin move, his eyes open. He pulls the rope, which zips out of snow towards the other end of the ledge. TAYLOR staggers hauls himself along the rope, at the other end of which i A partly snow-covered DALLAS WOOLF, deceased. His LEFT HA frozen in the grip of death around the other end of the R on his wrist, the luminous-face WATCHFACE (SCENE 99) says

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Been looking for you, Snowman. DALLAS’ EXPRESSION is a frozen moment of illuminated outr he too should be subject to the laws of nature. TAYLOR’S prods the brittle arc of his proud blue patrician nose. T switches on DALLAS’ HEAD LAMP =~ it blinds him! He LAUGHS

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: No offence - I would piss on your grave — but I’d for sure freeze my dick off doing it, know what I mean? DALLAS is frozen upright against the wall so that TAYLOR RIP him off the ice like a strip of velcro in order to ge COILS OF ROPE on the dead man’s shoulders ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yes Virginia, there is a Santa Claus ~~~ Now TAYLOR can also reach DALLAS’ PACK HARNESS. He manage difficulty to remove the PACK from the frozen corpse, now on the ground, then starts inspecting the CONTENTS ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: And this year he’s brought you -~- an oxygen cylinder! Just what I needed! (HE TAKES A HIT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meat Bars! You shouldn’t have! (HE TAKES A BITE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Rocket Flare! For the boy who has everything! TAYLOR STUFFS the FLARE and a number of other useful item into the PACK. Still rummaging:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Where's the goddam radio? Jesus! The one thing I actually ASKED for! Always thought Santa sucked!  105 Finished packing, TAYLOR stares down again at DALLAS’ fro

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I don’t exactly know why I hated you so much, but I sure as hell did, Snowman. Probably cos you didn’t trust me. Finally, TAYLOR removes DALLAS’ ICE AXE which is still at to DALLAS’ RIGHT HAND. He studies it for a moment ...

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You think I’m a low-life, huh? I leave Harold to die, so’s I can go back to knock off his widow! Except you don’t even believe I can get off this mountain, do you? TAYLOR, wearing DALLAS’ HEAD-LAMPED HELMET, has by now do PACK, and makes ready to go. He looks again at the second in his hand, decides he doesn't need it, and buries the h the snow near DALLAS’ HEAD to form a crude erucifix.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: News flash Woolf: I'm going to have it all. See you in hell! TAYLOR turns away, and looks out over the edge of the led down the slippery white moon-lit slopes to safety below. CU: HAROLD'S WATCH ticking off the seconds By now HAROLD is almost delirious —- and almost frozen to ledge; the only movement we see is in his vapidly flicker Then he HEARS it — a VOICE - a distant, urgent voice ~ an talking to him - he’s suddenly sure of it! HAROLD'S POV: standing before him on the ledge, a large b SHAPE ~ almost like the shape of a man — and it has somet like an AXE in its hand, raised aloft, as if to strike hi

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: No? This is Santa Claus baby. Tell you what -- I'll give you Miss Mammogram for Xmas -- if you just fuckun’ snap out of it and talk to me man!  106

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Taylor?!! Is that you?!!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (RIPPING HIS GOGGLES OFF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to disappoint you Virginia,

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What's happening? TAYLOR kneels to supply HAROLD with LIQUID and comfort

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: New plan! Altered situation assessment!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Actually --~ I am kinda glad you showed up.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yeah? Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: HARGLD
dialogues.text: I had just absolutely definitely decided that I do not want to die up here.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: That's what I wanted to hear!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yeah -- see I thought -~ there’s two billion guys on the planet - and any one of them’d take better care of Cindy than you would. Meanwhile TAYLOR is applying OXYGEN, more LIQUID and MEAT HAROLD’S FACE, as well as uncoiling ROPES, repacking the PACK, and Stripping down the frame of the new one to make basket-brace for HAROLD'S LEG, which TAYLOR now prods:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Feel anything?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Not really. What’s that mean? Now TAYLOR theatrically produces a big KNIFE; JOKINGLY:

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Means gangrene and I’ve gotta cut it off. Now. Save us both a lot of trouble later, dig?  107

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think Cindy is kind of into the idea of her husband coming home with two legs, you know? They do their "Victory" handshake, and then TAYLOR clips through HAROLD’S HARNESS. While he straps the dead leg in BRACE, and HAROLD winces in newly revived pain, TAYLOR pr beautifully thin FLASK.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Drink! 'Cos this is gonna hurt like hell.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Xmas Present from Dallas. Morphine base.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This isn't -- ouch! -- like you Taylor. Pain mitigation?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Must be going all new-fangled in my old age. You should see some of the other tricks I got in here. Now ~~ listen up: we got rope for a three hundred foot lower. What we’re gonna do is --~ 103: EXT/INT : CLAYBORN’S TENT: DAWN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While MALIK KNEELS OUTSIDE performing his dawn prayers, J stalks around him and bursts into the alert CLAYBORN’S TE

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Chopper’s on its way up!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: Any word from Taylor?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s been two days now, CLAYBORN ponders this provocative news .,.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYBORN
dialogues.text: We'll give him two more hours. Two hours! Understood?  108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roped HAROLD ~ an ICE AXE strapped to each wrist — bo down an iced rock face at a controlled but harrowing pace time his damaged leg makes contact with rock - ie often — cracks through his synapses like high country lightning. The pace slows, then stops. HAROLD grimly hobbles himself firm footing, and tugs the rope to signal that he is in p CU: the exhausted but hopeful HAROLD. AT THE TOP OF THE ROPE: TAYLOR breaks the belay and rapid down after it. The WIND is stronger again ... TAYLOR arrives above the waiting HAROLD, then manoeuvres down beside him. RED SKY in the Morning, HAROLD’S warning

dialogues.text: (FURIOUSLY RECOILING ROPE)

dialogues.text: Okay! It's holding!

dialogues.text: (SHRUGS)
